answers.answer: My advice is to have your blood sugar checked (a fasting blood sugar test).  If it is normal, then you probably don't have diabetes, however, only your doctor can confirm that.  Aside from a fasting blood test, testing your blood sugar when you wake up, before eating, and 2 hours after eating, and keeping a record of those levels for a period of a few days will give you a true picture of your blood sugar.  If the levels are all normal (your physician will let you know what your normal level should be), then you're okay when it comes to diabetes.  Most people have experienced limbs falling asleep in the situations you've described...it comes from cutting off circulation to your extremities...however, only a qualified health professional can tell you whether you have diabetes or whether you're worrying unnecessarily.  Hope this helps;o)

Sorry to be prescriptive, but you really ought to eat more often, and get more exercise - from my own experience, I've found myself doing much better when I do follow my own advice (which isn't all the time). Over a short period of time, you'll find the tingling sensation much less when you do exercise.
